awd_titl_txt: Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment: Oceanographic Cable
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition,  maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any U.S. university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, on behalf of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS), proposes to continue the procurement of electro-mechanical oceanographic cables and torque-balanced wire rope to meet the needs of UNOLS ships for a five-year period beginning 1 January 2017.

por.por_cntn:
The major objective of this grant was to procure electro-mechanical oceanographic cables and torque-balanced wire rope to meet the needs of the ships in the U.S. academic research fleet.  Since 1982, similar efforts to manage the NSF Wire Pool have resulted in an efficient system for the U.S. academic research fleet. The management oversight has kept the wire pool inventory and the distribution of these cables under close supervision. It has enabled swift and efficient procurements to meet the future needs and prompt distribution of cables to each UNOLS ship as the need arises. The inventory is maintained in two U.S. storage locations, one on the east coast and the other on the west coast, which reduces the cost of shipping to requesting institutions.

A total of 23 tension members were purchased through this grant including .322 in. diameter electro-mechanical cable, .322 in. diameter electro-optical cable, .498 in. diameter coaxial cable, 9/16 in. diameter 3x19 trawl wire, .680 in. diameter coaxial cable, .681 in. power optic cable, and 9/16 in. diameter Plasma HiCo synthetic rope. Distributions of 25 full reels and 1 partial reel of wire were made to research vessels at 10 institutions.

This grant also funded the testing of vessel tension members as required in the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) Research Vessel Safety Standard.  Funds from this grant were used to maintain and enhance a wire database which tracks the inventory and the activity of distributed wires through their useful life. The information derived from this database will help to inform future planning for replacement of wire in use onboard vessels and new inventory purchases, as well as new cable designs.

Additional work completed under this grant included:

  • An assessment of synthetic cable as a possible alternative for steel armored .322 in. diameter electro-mechanical cable.
  • An evaluation of the benefits of lubricating steel tension members more frequently at sea compared with lubricating annually while in port.
  • Evaluation of .681 in. diameter power optic cable products from different manufacturers using laboratory Cyclic Bend Over Sheave (CBOS) and cable compression tests.
  • Testing and evaluation of several synthetic rope products intended for coring applications.
  • Testing of the breaking strength of 9/16 in. diameter wire rope when used over rotating sheaves designed for .681 in. diameter cable.

Last Modified: 02/23/2023
Modified by: Richard P Trask
